ygData.subject: Question Re: HyperNEAT Speciate
ygData.msgSnippet: Functional fixedness is not an issue. The methodology of applying a Hypercube network comprised of a richer functional vocabulary to a substrate network

Subject: Question Re: HyperNEAT Speciate
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=281645563; y=ifo072XC1PHmn3UHHq4coX4e7nGcPH42KHR7ag0MQKSRsA

Functional fixedness is not an issue. The methodology of applying a 
Hyperc=
ube network comprised of a richer functional vocabulary to a 
substrate net=
work strongly coupled to the problem definition (i.e. 
inputs and outputs),=
 is the core feature. There is no reason that 
evolved complexification of =
both the Hypercube and substrate networks 
can not be performed. The guidel=
ine being adding complexity to the 
substrate network only to the degree th=
at the combined effects of 
hypercube functional vocabulary and topology ac=
hieve the problem 
threshold performance criteria within practical expendit=
ure of 
computational time/resources.

As an example, consider the multipli=
city of mathematical formulations 
considered for data modeling on the zunz=
un.com website (tens of 
thousands). The importance of the hypercube functi=
onal vocabulary 
lies in the ability express a useful mathematical relation=
ship with 
minimal additional search space, and be extensible (i.e. lego 
b=
uilding block approach). If the hypercube functional vocabulary is 
too sim=
plistic only, then the search space is inordinately increased 
by shear num=
bers trying to achieve representation by brute force 
(i.e. such as a Taylo=
r series expansion to achieve a Sine function).

Then there is the need for=
 the hypercube functional vocabulary to 
contain proximity based applicatio=
n mapping/limit functions which 
allow multiple, fundamentally different ma=
thematical expressions, to 
coevolved in separate sub-partitions of the sea=
rch space, to address 
underlying problem discontinuities. Again, the guide=
line being adding 
complexity only to achieve the problem threshold perform=
ance criteria 
within practical expenditure of computational time/resources=
.

This is why I believe that the hypercube functional vocabulary of 
activ=
ation functions require the ability to maintain additional 
associated evol=
ved parameters, rather than simply Y=3Df(X).

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, =
Stephen Waits <steve@...> wrote:
>
> 
> On Apr 28, 2007, at 3:53 PM, afcarl=
2 wrote:
> 
> > The attractiveness of evolving
> > global relationships in =
the Hypercube network is self-apparent, 
but
> > the set of useful problems=
 in which the substrate network made up 
of
> > only input and output nodes=
 seems limiting.
> 
> Right.  With HyperNEAT, I assumed that you would (man=
ually, a 
priori)  
> locate hidden nodes on the substrate.  And, yes, some=
 evolutionary  
> mechanism needs to be devised so that substrate configura=
tions may  
> also be evolved.  Ken seemed to agree, and I wonder if they'r=
e  
> already working on this?
> 
> With or without that mechanism, adding =
evolvability of activation  
> functions feels complex to me... in the sens=
e that it's probably  
> unnecessary.  But, I don't know, it's just a feeli=
ng.  If you  
> formally compare with and without activation evolution, I'd=
 
certainly  
> like to see the results.
> 
> Now, in your case, if you're =
not putting any hidden nodes on the  
> substrate, I can see how this would=
 help; however, I wonder if 
it's  
> enough?  Just doesn't seem like you'r=
e going to get very far 
without  
> using hidden nodes.
> 
> --Steve
>
